Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: "Correlation of Explosibility and Dispersion Characteristics of Combustible Engineered Nanomaterials"

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1321581
The fast growth in the production and use of nanomaterials has overcome the rate at which the hazards associated with these materials have been studied. While most of the studies on this aspect have been devoted for the understanding of nanomaterial toxicology resulted from workplace exposure, very little attention has been given to the fire and explosion hazards associated with combustible engineered nanomaterials. Thus, there is an urgent need for technical criteria from which the fire and explosion risk associated with combustible engineered nano materials can be quantified. Existing research on dust explosions hazards involving micro-sized dust materials have concluded that the severity of a confined dust explosion could increase as the particle size decreases to a certain level after which the particle size has no significant effect. As the result, there are many uncertainties that prevent making generalized conclusions that explains the behaviors of both micro and nano sized particles in dust explosion phenomenon. Therefore, thorough understanding will bring forward BROADER IMPACTS leading to the development of comprehensive experimental and theoretical information for supporting regulations and risk analysis for the use and production (intended/unintended) of nanomaterials.
In this study, commercially available metallic and non-metallic combustible engineered nanomaterials, together with their micro-scale counterparts, will be investigated. The conventional explosibility characteristics, essential in determining the likelihood and severity of a dust explosion, of these nanomaterials in terms of minimum explosive concentration (MEC), maximum pressure (Pmax), maximum pressure increase rate ([dP/dt]max), and minimum ignition temperature (MIT) will be evaluated experimentally. Further, because nanomaterials have propensity to agglomerate; and because the degree of agglomeration have a significant effect on the explosion behavior, it is critical to have a complete understanding of the dispersion and agglomeration behavior of nanomaterials and determine the relationship between the corresponding particle diameter and surface area and the ignition tendencies. This extensive investigation will provide more insight in potential correlations between the maximum rate of pressure rise and the properties of nanomaterials such as chemical composition, surface area, diameter, porosity of nanomaterial aggregates, etc. The results will serve as the basis for the development of the fundamental theory of nano dust explosion. This justifies the INTELLECTUAL MERIT of this project.
Because of the limited information available about this area and the uncertainty in the behavior of nanomaterials, the proposed research can be considered as a "high-risk" project. However, the research outcomes from this work have the potential for providing valuable qualitative and quantitative information that will contribute to address the safety issues encountered by industry regarding estimation of the explosion risks associated with engineered nanomaterials ("high-payoff"). Therefore, this research fits better the requirements for a NSF EAGER program instead a standard NSF program, which is intended for more established areas of research. The research proposed will employ existing equipments at our laboratories at Texas A&M University to study the dust explosion for combustible engineered nanomaterials. The results from the proposed research will set the foundations so that extensive long-term research projects could be realized to achieve complete understanding of related phenomena such as combustion mechanism and explosion properties. Further, this research will help to establish robust and consistent test methodologies in order to quantify the fire and explosion risks associated with engineered nanomaterials. This project will be valuable in determining the areas where a gap in knowledge exists and where future research should be focused.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Potential to advance knowledge

Several equipment was applied in this study to understand the properties of Carbon Nano fibers (CNFs). For example, scanning electronic microscopy (SEM) pictures show that each fiber looks like a stick with 100 nm in diameter and a couple of dozens um in length. In addition, these fibers do not exist as single fiber. Instead, hundreds of fibers agglomerate together and form “nests”. Besides, Thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) is a method measuring weight change as a function of increasing temperature. It is used to understand how CNFs react with air at different temperatures up to 1000°C. In addition, dust explosion is a very complicated process, which is even not fully understood till now. This study used a self-built equipment to test some properties when CNFs explode. Experiment results show several interesting results. For example, this study found that iron content (catalyst used to produce CNF’s) promoted the explosion of CNF’s: pyrophoric iron nanoparticles act like “sparks” within “nest”.

In addition, the process of dispersion of combustible dusts can result in particle breakage due to shearing actions and thus, can lead to the creation of smaller particles, leading to higher consequence events than anticipated. In regard to this thought, another area of investigation that this study focused on was to observe the particle breakage of dusts due to dispersion. SEM grids were installed in the vessel prior to dispersion to capture the CNF’s as they disperse. Post-dispersion, grids and the dust sample lying in the bottom of the vessel were analyzed using SEM. The SEM images are as shown in figure 1.

 

Based on the images the following could be concluded: -

  1. Dispersion of carbon nanoparticles results in breaking of agglomerates
  2. CNF’s original clusters break and are dispersed into thin fibers (can be seen post-dispersion grid image of CNF’s) due to shear/collision induced by dispersion phenomena
  3. The CNF’s tend to re-agglomerate and form clusters, like the original sample, but the clusters formation is different and the original shape is not retained (can be seen in post-dispersion vessel’s bottom CNF’s)

It highlights the importance of having knowledge of the particle size distribution and characteristics at the point of ignition in the cloud, in accurately modeling possible explosions.

Combining all these experimental results with theoretical studies on heat transfer, mass transfer, kinetic reactions, and shear force interactions, this study proposed and modified models to explain these findings, providing us and others with a better understanding about dust explosion process.

Broader Impacts: Potential to benefit society and contribute to desired societal outcomes

Combustible particles are of potential risk of dust explosion. For example, Imperial Sugar Refinery incident in Georgia killed 14 people and injured another 38. There are countless others. When it comes to nanoparticles such as CNF’s, the increased ration of surface over volume may promote their risk of combustion and explosion and the breaking of nanomaterials can further elevate the risk.

This study conducted tests to understand risk of CNF’s in terms of fire and explosion. For example, outcomes of this study answered these following questions:

  • How much energy needed to ignite CNFs?
  • What’s the minimum temperature for CNFs to burn?
  • What is the minimum concentration of CNFs required to cause an explosion within a confined area?
  • How strong an explosion of CNFs can be?
  • Does CNF’s break during dispersion, increasing surface area for combustion?

It is used to understand how CNFs react with air at different temperatures up to 1000°C. In addition, dust explosion is a very complicated process, which is even not fully understood till now. This study used a self-built equipment to test some properties when CNFs explode. Experiment results show several interesting results. For example, this study found that iron content (catalyst used to produce CNFÆs) promoted the explosion of CNFÆs: pyrophoric iron nanoparticles act like "sparks" within "nest". In addition, the process of dispersion of combustible dusts can result in particle breakage due to shearing actions and thus, can lead to the creation of smaller particles, leading to higher consequence events than anticipated. In regard to this thought, another area of investigation that this study focused on was to observe the particle breakage of dusts due to dispersion. SEM grids were installed in the vessel prior to dispersion to capture the CNFÆs as they disperse. Post-dispersion, grids and the dust sample lying in the bottom of the vessel were analyzed using SEM. The SEM images are as shown in figure 1. Based on the images the following could be concluded: - Dispersion of carbon nanoparticles results in breaking of agglomerates CNFÆs original clusters break and are dispersed into thin fibers (can be seen post-dispersion grid image of CNFÆs) due to shear/collision induced by dispersion phenomena The CNFÆs tend to re-agglomerate and form clusters, like the original sample, but the clusters formation is different and the original shape is not retained (can be seen in post-dispersion vesselÆs bottom CNFÆs) It highlights the importance of having knowledge of the particle size distribution and characteristics at the point of ignition in the cloud, in accurately modeling possible explosions. Combining all these experimental results with theoretical studies on heat transfer, mass transfer, kinetic reactions, and shear force interactions, this study proposed and modified models to explain these findings, providing us and others with a better understanding about dust explosion process. Broader Impacts: Potential to benefit society and contribute to desired societal outcomes Combustible particles are of potential risk of dust explosion. For example, Imperial Sugar Refinery incident in Georgia killed 14 people and injured another 38. There are countless others. When it comes to nanoparticles such as CNFÆs, the increased ration of surface over volume may promote their risk of combustion and explosion and the breaking of nanomaterials can further elevate the risk. This study conducted tests to understand risk of CNFÆs in terms of fire and explosion. For example, outcomes of this study answered these following questions: How much energy needed to ignite CNFs? WhatÆs the minimum temperature for CNFs to burn? What is the minimum concentration of CNFs required to cause an explosion within a confined area? How strong an explosion of CNFs can be? Does CNFÆs break during dispersion, increasing surface area for combustion? With all these questions answered, industries that process CNFs can design their facility accordingly to prevent and mitigate dust explosion of CNFs. In addition, CNF industries widely apply two processing methods: milling them to smaller ones and treating them in extremely high temperatures (1500°C and 3000°C).
